title: Cat. 161  Finger Ring with Engraved Gemstone, 1st century A.D.
publication_title: Roman Art at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Finger Ring with Engraved Gemstone  
Gemstone: Roman, 1st century A.D.; ring: modern  
Gemstone: sardonyx; ring: gold; 1.5 × 2.4 × 2.5 cm (1/2 × 15/16 × 1 in.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, bequest of Janis H. Palmer, 1986.898

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">This oval sardonyx intaglio gem would have been used as a personal seal in antiquity, set in a signet ring—although the present ring is modern. The intaglio shows a horse, depicted in profile, with its head lowered, as if to graze. As is common for such depictions of horses on Roman gems, one front leg (here the left) is raised below the horse’s body. In this particular example the hoof is lifted so high that it appears as though the horse is scratching the underside of his stomach—a playful image, presenting a gesture that is actually a physical impossibility for the real animal. The main body of the horse is shown in broad naturalistic curves, but the legs, face, mane, and tail are much more stylized—with the hooves and joints of the leg rounded, the tail bushy and full, and the mane rising in rhythmic spikes, which at the front of the head indeed appear to replace the ears. This is a characterful representation.

The horse was a relatively popular motif for intaglio seals in the Roman Empire, with a good number of surviving examples showing a single horse with its head lowered, as if to graze, as in this case. In other examples the horse is rolling on the ground, galloping, or rearing. Horses were a sign of wealth and prestige in the Roman context, and a symbol of sportsmanship besides for the young men who Strabo tells us would race their chariots on the Campus Martius, just outside of Rome’s city walls. Indeed, horses had also been a motif in Greek glyptic art from the most ancient times, presumably for similar reasons. The horse was thus an enduring symbol of victory, status, and wealth in the ancient world. More broadly too, profile images of a range of other animals and livestock were also popular in the Roman context, with bulls and boars commonly appearing, as well as lions, and occasionally even such exotic beasts as the rhinoceros or crocodile. Each of these animals no doubt readily invited associations of power, or manly prowess, recommending them as a popular choice in Roman glyptic arts.  
Nicola Barham

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">See also cat. 137, Fragment of a Cameo Portraying Emperor Tiberius, Method. The high-resolution photography reveals grooves that suggest that the gem was cut with a lap wheel and a slurry abrasive (most probably corundum and a lubricant like olive oil). Thanks to Martin Henig for this observation.For the method of carving gems in antiquity, see the J. Paul Getty Museum’s short documentary, The Art of Gem Carving: http://www.getty.edu/art/collection/video/142937/the-art-of-gem-carving/.

This image of a horse with a raised front hoof was quite common, though other versions kept the hoof lower. See Pannuti, Catalogo della Collezione Glittica, cat. 267.2 (Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Napoli, Naples, 155879, 1st century A.D.); Henig, Classical Gems, cat. 223 (ill.) (Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge, England, B239[CM], 1st century B.C.), cat. 362 (ill.) (B239\*[CM], 1st century B.C.); Maaskant-Kleibrink, Catalogue of the Engraved Gems, vol. 2, cat. 408 (Rijksmuseum, Koninklijk Penningkabinet, The Hague, 1257, second half of the 1st century B.C./beginning of the 1st century A.D.); Weiss, Antike Gemmen in deutschen Sammlungen, cat. 294, pl. 41 (Germanisches Nationalmuseum, Nuremberg, SiSr 1725, second half of the 1st century B.C.); Walters, Catalogue of the Engraved Gems, cat. 2404 (British Museum, London, 1865,0712.213, 1st/3rd century A.D., head lowered, left foot raised), cat. 2405 (British Museum, London, 1867,0507.630, 1st/3rd century A.D., left forefoot raised); Henig and MacGregor, Catalogue of the Engraved Gems, cat. 9.75, fig. 9.75 (Ashmolean Museum, Oxford, England, Fortnum 168, 1st century A.D.), also in Middleton, Engraved Gems from Dalmatia, cat. 223; Nestorović, Images of the World, cat. 49, pls. 5, 12 (Narodni Muzej, Ljubljana, Slovenia, R 5426, 1st century B.C./1st century A.D., a particularly stylized version); Wagner and Boardman, Collection of Classical and Eastern Intaglios, cat. 481; Vollenweider, Deliciae Leonis, cats. 220–22, 224 (1st century B.C., with the ground line for cat. 221 set at an angle to give the effect of a confused semi-gambol up a hill).

See the examples in note 2 above, and also, e.g., Henig and MacGregor, Catalogue of the Engraved Gems, cat. 9.74, fig. 9.74 (Ashmolean Museum, Oxford, England, 1941.553, 1st century B.C./1st century A.D.); Walters, Catalogue of the Engraved Gems, cat. 2406 (British Museum, London, 1872,0604.275, c. 3rd century A.D.), cat. 2407 (1917,0501.1459, 1st/3rd century A.D.); Zienkiewicz, Roman Gems from Caerleon, “Pack-ass” entry (National Museum Wales, Caerleon, 81.79H/4.22, found in a deposit dated to A.D. 85/110), also in Zienkiewicz, Legionary Fortress Baths at Caerleon, cat. 22, pp. 131–32; Weiss, Antike Gemmen in deutschen Sammlungen, cat. 295, pl. 41 (Germanisches Nationalmuseum, Nuremberg, SiSt 1730, 1st century B.C.); Pannuti, Catalogo della Collezione Glittica, cat. 260 (Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Napoli, Naples, 27652, 1st century A.D.); Maaskant-Kleibrink, Description of the Collections, cat. 46 (Rijksmuseum G. M. Kam, Nijmegen, the Netherlands, GN BA VII 48/G46, Augustan period); Schmidt, Antike Gemmen in deutschen Sammlungen, glass-pastes 19–52; Brandt et al., Antike Gemmen in deutschen Sammlungen, cat. 2245 (1st century B.C.), cat. 2838 (3rd/4th century A.D.); Gesztelyi, Luxus gemmarum, cat. 54; Vollenweider, Deliciae Leonis, cats. 223, 225 (1st century B.C.). For a similar example, where the horse seems to be drinking from a cup set on the ground, see Guiraud, Intailles et camées romains, cat. 59.

For the horse rolling on the ground: Schmidt, Antike Gemmen in deutschen Sammlungen, glass-pastes 1955–57; Walters, Catalogue of the Engraved Gems, cat. 2400 (British Museum, London, 1923,0401.304, 1st/3rd century A.D.). For the horse galloping or rearing: Weiss, Antike Gemmen in deutschen Sammlungen, cats. 297–302, pl. 41 (Germanisches Nationalmuseum, Nuremberg, SiSt 1724, 1733, 1737, 1742, 1750, 1755, Roman period); Ţeposu-Marinescu, Catalogul, cat. 50 (Muzeul Judeţean de Istorie şi Artă, Zalău, Romania, 408/1966, Roman period, with the horse apparently almost gamboling, in this case). For various other poses: Walters, Catalogue of the Engraved Gems, cat. 2401 (British Museum, London, 1917,0501.1193, 3rd/5th century A.D., kneeling), cat. 2402 (1842,0728.4, 1st/2nd century A.D., standing, front left leg raised, with palm), cat. 2403 (1904,0204.545, 1st/3rd century A.D., walking right), cat. 2408 (1917,0501.559, 3rd century A.D. or later, standing, facing left), cat. 2409 (1867,0507.162\*\*\*, 1st/3rd century A.D., standing, cross over its back); Henig and MacGregor, Catalogue of the Engraved Gems, cat. 9.73, fig. 9.73 (Ashmolean Museum, Oxford, England, 2003.88, 1st century A.D., with palm branch); Pannuti, Catalogo della Collezione Glittica, cats. 257–59 (Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Napoli, Naples, 135049, 120300, 158795, 1st century A.D., various poses); Maaskant-Kleibrink, Catalogue of the Engraved Gems, cat. 1022 (Rijksmuseum, Koninklijk Penningkabinet, The Hague, 1261, 2nd/3rd century A.D., with victory palm branch); Wagner and Boardman, Collection of Classical and Eastern Intaglios, cat. 482 (front hoof raised forward), cat. 483 (prancing). In other instances, the horse is accompanied by a human figure; see, e.g., Marshall, Catalogue of the Finger Rings, cat. 1198, pl. 29 (British Museum, London, 1917,0501.1198, 3rd/5th century A.D.).

See Strabo, Geography, 5.3.8.

See, e.g., Richter, Catalogue of Engraved Gems, cats. 105–06, pl. 18; Brandt, Antike Gemmen in deutschen Sammlungen, cat. 257, pl. 30 (grazing).

For livestock, see, e.g., D’Ambrosio, Gli ori di Oplontis, cat. 55, pl. 24 (Pompei Soprintendenza Archaeologica, OP 3315, 1st century B.C./1st century A.D.), cat. 59, pl. 26 (OP 3420, late 1st century B.C./early 1st century A.D.), both of bulls. For the lion, see, e.g., Weiss, Antike Gemmen in deutschen Sammlungen, cats. 275–80, pls. 38–39 (Germanisches Nationalmuseum, Nuremberg, 1729, 1735, 1740, 1744, 1756, 1758, Roman period); Henig, Handbook of Roman Art, no. 122 (from Salamis, Cyprus; Cyprus Museum, Nicosia, 1st century B.C.). For the rhinoceros, see Walters, Catalogue of the Engraved Gems, cat. 2342 (British Museum, London, 1814,0704.1408, 1st/3rd century A.D.), also in Richter, Engraved Gems, vol. 2, cat. 377. For the crocodile, see Pannuti, Catalogo della Collezione Glittica, cat. 267.4 (Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Napoli, Naples, 155879, 1st century A.D.).

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 161 Finger Ring with Engraved Gemstone, 1st century A.D.
